summary:
Midoriya Izuku is still the biggest hero nerd to walk the earth and not even being Number One is going to change that.

Now if only he could remember to tell his fans that he is Pro Hero Deku.

So. I have nagged and nagged and nagged and finally figured I should do it myself.
Behold!
The long awaited second chapter!
I might even write another, we'll see.
Mind the tags though because we have some sensitive topics.
OH.
Also the first chapter has been edited (again) so you might wanna re-read the entire thing.
Have fun at Hero Con!

Love,

10 Questions Answered By Number One Hero, Deku, and Which One Surprised Us the Most!

It was only six months after the aforementioned con that Deku had been asked about one of the more memorable moments with fans.
Deku had paused for a second, a single face and a single incident coming to mind. He smiled and settled into the retelling of this story a touch more seriously then before. He was slower, a bit quieter as he spoke and easily held us as his interviewers captive with the splay of emotions he didn’t hide.
“I’ll change the names for privacy reasons but…ironically enough, as all my best moments tend to be, I was at Hero Con. ”
It’s the bright red shoes he sees first. 
There are a lot of bright red shoes, easily dismissed as cosplay for Deku, casual or otherwise. But these-  these  are not the shoes worn by  Deku,  these are the ones worn by  Izuku Midoriya. 
Quirkless people, with the extra toe joint, with a missing bit of evolution, who need that extra support for that one part of their anatomy that is different from those who developed a Quirk.
Any Quirkless would recognize that brand. Izuku doesn’t know if the fans at large know the significance of those bright red sneakers, but for this child he sees, tiny body jerking itself around as if searching for someone not there…

 Izuku knows. 

He’s cosplaying himself at this con. In the very first version of his uniform, with his face covered, made by his mother with normal fabric, not the special Hero-Grade fabrics he wears almost exclusively today.
He takes a breath and makes a beeline towards the child, weaving through the crowd until the child stands in front of him- dressed in a rendition of All Might’s Silver Age costume with Deku’s iconic red sneakers.
Black fluffy hair, wide blue eyes set in the face of a child barely 10 years old.
Time seems to slow as a small space is carved around them, when Izuku lowers himself down to kneel in front of her, a smile curving his lips, as he gently tugs his hood back so his smile is visible.
“Hello,” Izuku says as blue eyes go  wide  in recognition, as her jaw drops in awe. “I’m Deku. Are you alright?”
A moment, then another. A gleam of tears, then the girl snaps her jaw shut and leans forward, something desperate and despairing stealing over her so quickly, Izuku cannot help but see himself looking back.

 Can someone without a Quirk be like you? 


 “Can I be a hero like you?” 

The ghost of Izuku’s past, here and now, a lifetime later. 
Still, he doesn’t answer. A beat of silence and her expression doesn’t change.
“What’s your name?”
“Haru Tanaka. I want to be a  hero. ”
Haru says it like it’s the only thing she will ever want. She says it like it hurts, like if she says it enough, if she says it  loud  enough, it’ll mean something more. That someone will  look at her  and say, “  You’ll be a great hero!” .
In the exact way only one person has ever told a Quirkless child so long ago.
Izuku wants to cry, wants to scream that she can from the top of the tallest building he can jump to. A second later, It’s Deku that reaches out and hugs her. It’s Deku that tells her-
“You are very brave.”
It’s  Izuku  that tightens his arms, it’s  Izuku  that whispers as fiercely as he can into her ear-
“You are enough, all by yourself. You can be anything you want, as long as you work hard enough for it. It won’t be easy. It will be hard. People will tell you that you  can’t. ”
Her breath is hitching as her hands grip tightly into his costume, the one his mother made with all the love and care, just the same as Haru’s parent probably made her own costume and Izuku’s heart aches.
It was so long ago. The words of the teachers at Aldera, of his classmates, of  Kacchan.  They still tug at him, almost a decade later. He can barely remember their names, their faces, but their words stick in his memory all these years later.
